titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Una Hanbury Papers, 1910-1994, bulk 1966-1990, in the Archives of American Art AAA.hanbuna
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Catherine S. Gaines and Kimberley Henze

note.p: This finding aid was created from a MARC collection-level record. 221286

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-06-29T11:25-0400

did.abstract: The papers of Una Hanbury measure 5.3 linear feet and date from 1910 to 1994, with the bulk of the material from 1966 to 1990. The collection documents the sculptor's career and the dispersal of her estate through business records, project files, subject files, printed material, and photographs. There is also a small amount of material relating to her personal life including correspondence with friends and family and photographs from various stages of her life.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Una Hanbury (1904-1990) was a sculptor in Washington, D.C. and Santa Fe, New Mexico. Hanbury was born in Middlesex, England, in 1904; the incorrect birth date of 1909 that she submitted to Who's Who and other biographical reference sources is cited in numerous published articles. Hanbury [née Rawnsley] exhibited artistic talent as a young child and received instruction from animal artist Frank Calderon. After graduation from London's Polytechnic School of Art, she studied for three years at the Royal Academy. Jacob Epstein was her most influential teacher.

Soon after completing her formal education, Una Rawnsley became Una Hanbury and devoted herself full-time to being a wife and mother. During World War II she left England for Bermuda and brought her family to the United States once the war was over. Hanbury settled in Washington, D.C., where she resumed her sculpting career, completing many large scale commissions for public buildings such as the Medical Examiners Building, Baltimore, and St. Mark's Lutheran Church, Springfield, Virginia, among others. She developed a fine reputation as a portrait sculptor, and commissions included busts of Rachel Carson, Enrico Fermi, Buckminster Fuller, Laura Gilpin, Richard Neutra, Georgia O'Keeffe, Robert Oppenheimer, S. Dillon Ripley, and Andrés Segovia. In addition, animals--particularly horses--were a favorite subject since childhood; sculptures were commissioned by several zoos, and horse portraits often were commissioned by owners.
In 1970, Una Hanbury relocated to Santa Fe, New Mexico, where she continued working well into old age and became a significant force in the art life of that region.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Una Hanbury measure 5.3 linear feet and date from 1910 to 1994, with the bulk of the material from 1966 to 1990. The collection documents the sculptor's career and the dispersal of her estate through business records, project files, subject files, printed material, and photographs. There is also a small amount of material relating to her personal life including correspondence with friends and family and photographs from various stages of her life.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into seven series.

list.item: Series 4: Subject Files, circa 1924-1985 (Box 4, OV 7; 1.0 linear feet)
Series 5: Estate of Una Hanbury, 1990-1994 (Boxes 4-5; 0.6 linear feet)

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Una Hanbury papers were donated to the Archives of American Art by the artist's daughter, Jillian Poole, in 1999 and 2006.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives' Washington, D.C., Research Center. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice. Contact Reference Services for more information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Una Hanbury papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Una Hanbury papers, 1910-1994, bulk 1966-1990. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed and the finding aid written by Catherine S. Gaines. The finding aid was modified by Stephanie Ashley in October 2001 prior to EAD conversion. All duplicates were returned to the donor at her request. The second accession was processed to a minimal level, merged into the collection, and the finding aid updated by Kimberley Henze in 2015.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Personal Papers series begins with Hanbury's correspondence with family and friends. Memorabilia, comprised mainly of printed material, includes a brochure about Chelsea Pottery in Nassau run by her relative David Rawnsley, an announcement of daughter Jillian's marriage, a program of Queen Elizabeth's coronation, and theater programs. Public speaking records include by-laws and membership lists of the Capital Speakers Club, programs of the Capital Public Speaking Classes, speech notes, and instructor's comments. The series also contains some pencil drawings by Una Hanbury, executed 1926 to 1928, and a silkscreen by her grandson, Colin Poole, from 1970.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by folder title, and material within each folder is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business records documenting the career of Una Hanbury consist of correspondence with clients, dealers, and foundries, and include various gallery and associate files, consignment records, casting records, certificates of authenticity, speeches, writings, and a video-recorded sculpture demonstration on VHS from 1990.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by folder title, and material within each folder is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise noted, files include photographs--in fact, many consist of photographs only. If other record types such as correspondence, printed material, certificates of authenticity, casting records, sketches, 35-mm slides, color transparencies, and negatives are present, this information is noted for each title. Dates indicated reflect the contents of the folder, which may or may not correspond to the date of execution of the particular work.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Project files are arranged alphabetically by title/commission. Material within each folder is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains sketches, source material, and research on figures, forms, and types prearranged by subject. These materials manifest in news clippings, published journals, ink and pencil drawings, greeting cards, postcards, and scattered photographs and negatives. Oversized subject files are found in OV 7 and include ink and pencil drawings on paper pulled from the files Animals, Miscellaneous; Arms, Hands, Feet; and Bristlecone Pines.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Subject files are arranged alphabetically by subject name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in OV 7.

did.unittitle: Oversized Subject Files from Box 4, Folders 2, 4, 9-11

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Estate records document the dispersal--mainly through sale--of sculpture that remained unsold at the time of the artist's death. Saunders Sculpture International and its subsidiary, Perry House Galleries, represented the Estate of Una Hanbury.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by folder title, and material within each folder is arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Bust of Mrs. Ortiz y Pino (Concha)
Letters from Diana Hanbury King to Clients (A-B and R)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of articles, reviews, and letters to the editor written by Hanbury; exhibition material including catalogs, announcements, and invitations; publicity consisting of press releases and articles about Hanbury, her work, and the memorial service held for her; and obituaries. The series also includes miscellaneous clippings about friends, acquaintances, and subjects of interest as well as catalogs of sculptors' equipment and supplies.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Material within each folder is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes articles, reviews, and letters to the editor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Material concerns friends, acquaintances, and subjects of interest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Kildonan News, Spring 1985, and M Magazine, May-June, 1989

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes articles about Hanbury and her work appearing in newspapers, periodicals, newsletters, etc. Also includes news releases.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes photographs of works of art by Hanbury and photographs of Hanbury with family members, as a student, at work, and on her travels.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged into two subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Early works of Una Hanbury include loose pages from a photo album documenting work done by Hanbury while studying at the Royal Academy and exhibiting there, annotated with exhibition and prize information. This folder also include works done by her at ages 9 to 11; works done in Capri at ages 15 to 16; Don Quixote, Knight in Armour, and Valkyrie executed in 1920; and some travel photos of Capri from 1920.

There are also negatives, photographs, and 35-mm slides of miscellaneous works by Hanbury, including an exhibition installation. These folders contain works which may or may not also be present in Project or Subject files but were not placed within the latter groupings in the inherent organization received from the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographs of childhood and youth includes Una at age 6 with a model of a horse (the first photograph of her work); Una with her grandmother and at work on a sculpture in 1915; and Una in class at the Royal Academy in 1925. There is also an undated studio portrait.

Photographs of Una Hanbury include images at special events include the unveiling of the Gilpin bust in 1973; Louis Rosen's birthday picnic in 1978; the De Lattre inauguration in 1980; the unveiling of Phoenix in 1985; and the opening of the Guild for Religious Architecture exhibition which is undated. Unidentified occasions from 1982 and undated can also be found here in addition to travel photographs of Hanbury in Seville and Alaska[?]; formal and candid portraits, both undated and from 1964; and undated photographs of Hanbury with horses, at Goodwin Ranch, with her family, in her studio, and at a foundry.
